New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 On 23 May 2018 UNDP submitted a project proposal requesting for funding of the Environmental programme "UNDP Towards Environmental Sustainability in Cambodia". A revised version of the proposal was submitted on 10 July 2018.
The objective of the intervention is to enable Cambodia to attain the Sustainable Development goals, more specifically goal 15: life on land; goal 12: responsible consumption and production, and goal 7: affordable and clean energy.
The programme aims to design and implement innovative environmentally sustainable models in specifically targeted areas through public and private partnerships.
The programme will attain the following four outputs: -more areas placed under sustainable management -waste reduced, recycled and reused through application of circular economy models -improved access to clean, affordable, and sustainable energy for the rural poor -enabling policies developed and policy coordination enhanced.
The total amount of the contribution is 49 100 000 SEK, of which Sida is requested to contribute with 16 500 000 SEK.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Den 23 maj 2018 inkom UNDP med ansökan om finansiering av ett miljöprogram, "UNDP Towards Environmental Sustainability in Cambodia". En reviderad version av ansökan inlämnades den 10 juli 2018. Programmet kommer att genomföras under perioden 2018-2020.
Syftet med insatsen är att bistå Kambodja i att nå de globala utvecklingsmålen, mer specifikt mål 15: "skydda, återställa och främja ett hållbart nyttjande av landbaserade ekosystem, hålllbart bruka skogar, bekämpa ökenspridning, hejda och vrida tillbaka markförstöringen samt hejda förlusten av biologisk mångfald; mål 12: säkerställa hållbara konsumptions- och produktionsmönster; samt mål 7: säkerställa tillgången till en ekonomiskt överkomlig, tillförlitlig, hållbar och modern energi för alla.
Programmet avser främja miljömässigt hållbara modeller i riktade områden i samverkan med myndigheter, civilsamhälle samt genom publika/privata partnerskap. Genom programmet eftersträvas följande mål: 1) flera områden under hållbar naturvårdsskötsel 2) minskat, återanvänt avfall genom cirkulära ekonomiska modeller 3) bättrad tillgång till ren, ekonomisk tillgänglig, och hållbar energi för fattig landsbygdsbefolkning 4) utvecklande av miljöfrämjande policies och stärkt policykoordinering.
Insatsens totala belopp uppgår till 49,1 MSEK, utav vilket Sida ombeds bidra med 16 500 000 SEK.

The programme aims to contribute to Cambodia being able to attain the Sustainable Development Goals related to 1) natural resources management (NRM) & biodiversity conservation, 2) clean, affordable and sustainable energy and 3) circular economy. To achieve the overall objective, UNDP seeks to design and support project designs and tests innovative environmentally sustainable models in the targeted areas through public and private partnerships. Based on the demonstrated results, the project further identifies venues for scaling-up workable models by linking initiatives to existing and future UNDP programmes as well as bankable projects (e.g. loans). More specifically, the four following outputs have been identified: Output 1: More areas placed under sustainable management The degradation has negative effects not only on biodiversity and carbon sequestration capacities, but also on livelihoods of many rural people, especially those of women and the poor, who are dependent on forests for subsistence and income. The direct causes of degradation are related to the conversion of forests into different kinds of land concessions, including development activities, the unauthorized logging, encroachment and forest fires. The situation is further exacerbated by a growing demand of forest products, increased access to forested areas, weak forest governance and rural poverty. The programme aims to support 1) the creation and expansion of community based NRM institutions, 2) to demonstrate economically viable options for communities to engage in sustainable production of natural resources, including scaling up of sustainable charcoal initiative to the national level, and 3) operationalization of Payment for Ecosystems Services for two pilot sites. Output 2: Waste reduced, recycled and reused through application of circular economy models Cambodia faces challenges of rapidly growing municipal and industrial wastes. Meanwhile the industry sector remains energy inefficient. The project aims to introduce the concept of “circular economy” to promote sustainable management and use of wastes and energy. The following interventions will contribute to the second objective: 1) piloting of in selected municipalities and industries of two initiatives, including waste management in Siem Reap and the design of sanitary landfills for industrial and general waste in Kampong Channang 2) designing business approaches to industrial waste with the Special Economic Zones and the germent sector , and 3) provide strategic communication and awareness on successful outomes, and 4) support enabling policies and measures to mainstream circular economy models and the formulation of strategies for scaling up. Output 3: Improved access to clean, affordable, and sustainable energy for the rural poor Cambodia’s current and future energy policy focuses on hydropower, oil and coal as its main energy sources. This emphasis is assessed as creating challenges pertaining to the adverse environmental impacts, the risk of 10% of households to be left without grid access, an unstable and insecure energy supply, and the affordability of energy for much of the population. The programme objective is to support 1) an enabling policy environment to remove policy barriers, 2) build technical capacity for installing and maintaining quality solar energy systems and removing technical barriers to green energy, 3) contribute to the removing financial barriers for solar energy and building an enabling environment, and 4) contribute to reduced information barriers by awareness raising about effective provision of solar energy for productive use and increasing resilience of vulnerable groups targeted at poor households. Output 4: Enabling policies developed and policy coordination enhanced The programme aims to promotes the development of policies and a facilitation of a Technical Working Group on environment in order to strengthen coordination and information sharing on environmental issues. Through the contribution, UNDP aims to support policy development, while directly providing input into, and draw experiences from grassroot levels, including the community level, and by learning from innovative approaches that can be scaled up more broadly, while also looking at long term financial solutions, including loans and other types of engagement from the private sector.

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
11.6 - By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, including by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management.
11.6 - Till 2030 minska städernas negativa miljöpåverkan per person, bland annat genom att ägna särskild uppmärksamhet åt luftkvalitet samt hantering av kommunalt och annat avfall.
12.5 - By 2030, substantially reduce waste generation through prevention, reduction, recycling and reuse.
12.5 - Till 2030 väsentligt minska mängden avfall genom åtgärder för att förebygga, minska, återanvända och återvinna avfall.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
14.1 - By 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution.
14.1 - Till 2025 förebygga och avsevärt minska alla slags föroreningar i havet, i synnerhet från landbaserad verksamhet, inklusive marint skräp och tillförsel av näringsämnen.

15.1 - By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements.

15.1 - Till 2020 bevara, återställa och hållbart använda ekosystem på land och i sötvatten och deras ekosystemtjänster, särskilt skogar, våtmarker, berg och torra områden, i enlighet med de skyldigheter som anges i internationella överenskommelser.
3.9 - By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.
3.9 - Till 2030 väsentligt minska antalet döds- och sjukdomsfall till följd av skadliga kemikalier samt föroreningar och kontaminering av luft, vatten och mark.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
6.6 - By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
6.6 - Senast 2020 skydda och återställa de vattenrelaterade ekosystemen, däribland berg, skogar, våtmarker, floder, akviferer och sjöar.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

title.narrative: Decision on Contribution, UNDP Environmental Programme 2019-2020

description.narrative: While the programme experienced a slow start during the first six months of 2019 with administrative challenges, several achievements seem to have been accomplished since (especially within the areas of circular economy and policy-research related to energy). In May, the Embassy and Sida HQ provided comments on the latest draft of the circular economy roadmap (relating to output 2). The policy work has been supported through BESD, with funding from Sweden. The document is important in order to enable a long-term reform. In June, UNDP provided an update on the status of rural innovative off-grid solar energy investments (relating to output 3). UNDP has chosen a location for the investment, Steung Chrov, an island in the Tonle Sap lake, far from the grid and requiring an hour of boat ride to reach mainland. The village have 150 households of which 30 are female-headed (project target at least 20 female-headed households). UNDP has agreed with Ministry of Energy to employ a DC-minigrid technology for these investments. This means that the households get a solar home system on their roof. The panels will be connected in a grid system between the houses in the village, which creates more efficient use of produced electricity and better power stability for all. It also enhances the possibilities to attach cost-efficient batteries to the minigrid to store power to be used in evenings. It comes with a new business model in regard to financing operation and maintenance of the system, and families pay for their use of energy according to how much they want. This solution and delivery of a model DC-minigrid adds to the objective of the BESD project to provide innovative solar energy solutions to off-grid villages.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Career guidance - Swedish Public Employment Service - Finn Church Aid
COVID-19 Yrkesvägledning - Arbetsförmedlingen - Finska Kyrkans Utlandshjälp

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Det föreslagna projektet “Career Guidance and Counselling in Secondary Schools - the Bridge to Employment” (”Yrkesvägledning och rådgivning på gymnasienivå – bryggan till anställning”) är ett gemensamt åtagande av Arbetsförmedlingen, Finska Kyrkans Utlandshjälp (Finn Church Aid), kambodjanska Ministeriet för utbildning, ungdomar och idrott (MoEYS) och det Nationella Arbetsmarknadsinstitutet (NEA). Syftet är att skapa system som kan bistå ungdomar med bättre kunskap om arbetsmarknaden och relevanta utbildningsvägar.
För att åstadkomma detta kommer insatsen att etablera system för yrkesvägledning och rådgivning på gymnasienivå i tre pilotprovinser liksom att bidra till skapande av mobila arbetscentra med anknytning till utbildningssystemet. Avsikten är att detta system för information och vägledning om arbetsmarknaden byggs ut efterhand för att nå en nationell täckning. Insatsen bygger på erfarenheter från de olika projekt inom området som parterna har bedrivit under de senaste åren i Kambodja.
Projektet kommer att bidra till att skapa och förstärka institutionella processer och strukturer, bl.a. genom att stödja framtagande av riktlinjer och styrdokument för yrkesvägledning liksom att bygga upp moduler för utbildning av yrkesvägledare vid institut för lärarutbildning. Inom projektets ram kommer MoEYS och NEA att erbjudas teknisk assistans för kapacitetsutveckling för att säkerställa yrkesvägledning av hög kvalitet. Ett av projektets syften är att metodiskt samla erfarenheter av effektiva insatser för yrkesvägledning och informationsspridning som kan användas som underlag för kambodjanska myndigheters strategier och beslut för fortsatt utbyggnad. För detta ändamål kommer den pågående verksamheten i Battambang att byggas ut och expandera till ytterligare provinser. Ett antal nya rådgivare kommer att genomgå träning och kommer att erhålla stöd under projektets gång.
En av de viktigast delarna av projektet är att bidra till närmare samverkan mellan det formella utbildningssystemet och arbetsmarknaden, inte för att elever tidigt ska kunna erhålla anställning utan för att de kan få en bättre och mera relevant uppfattning om arbetsmarknaden och vägar in i den.
Projektet kommer att kombinera lokal kunskap och kontextförståelse med kunskap och erfarenhet från Finland och Sverige genom nära samarbete och samverkan med såväl olika offentliga som oberoende aktörer.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The proposed project, “Career Guidance and Counselling in Secondary Schools - the Bridge to Employment” is a joint venture by the Swedish National Employment Service, Finn Church Aid, the Cambodian Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports and the National Employment Agency. The aim is to provide youth with better understanding of the labour market and which educational pathways could lead to the desired jobs, and to enhance sustainable career development skills of Cambodian youth. This will be done by establishing quality career guidance and counselling (CGC) services in three target provinces’ secondary schools and in Mobile Job-Centres or Job-Centres with the goal of expanding the system nationwide at a later stage. The project structure and plan is based on lessons learned from earlier project phases implemented by the project partners. The project will institutionalise supportive processes and structures, e.g. by producing a CGC policy and by introducing Career Counsellor training as a part of teacher training in an existing teacher training institute. The project will give technical assistance for capacity building of governmental authorities in NEA and MoEYS to ensure quality CGC service provision. The project will also produce evidence-based information for the Royal Government of Cambodia on the most effective and appropriate model of CGC service delivery. This will entail expanding existing CGC services within and from Battambang province to two additional provinces to gain experience and collect data for deeper analysis. New Career Counsellors will be trained during the project implementation and supported in their work on school level. One of the main elements of the project is to create closer collaboration for CGC service provision between the formal education sector and the labour market, not with the aim to recruit students to work life too early, but to enhance the awareness of available and relevant study paths and improve youth’s soft skills, leading to meaningful sources of livelihoods in later life. For Cambodia’s economy to continue growing it needs motivated young professionals, who have the right kind of skills and education. With aligned CGC services guiding students in schools and after graduation this gap can be narrowed. The project will combine local knowledge and contextual requirements with know-how from Finland and Sweden, through fruitful collaboration combining different governmental and non-governmental actors as project partners.

The overall objective of the contribution is to contribute to increased labour market participation of youth after completing a meaningful education pathway, and to enhance sustainable career development skills of youth in Cambodia. The project objective is to establish evidence-based and quality career guidance and counselling services in three target provinces’ secondary schools and mobile Job-Centres/Job-Centres in Cambodia, with strong linkages to labour market, with potential for country wide scale-up. There are three expected outcomes of the intervention: Outcome 1: Secondary School students and Job-Centre customers have access to quality career guidance and counselling services in the three targeted provinces Outcome 2: Evidence emanating from research on the (cost) effectiveness of career guidance and counselling services is available for Cambodian Government’s further decision- and policy-making Outcome 3: Policymakers and education authorities develop policies, systems and mechanisms for further roll-out of career guidance and counselling services

tag.narrative: 4.4 - By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship.

4.4 - Till 2030 väsentligen öka det antal ungdomar och vuxna som har relevanta färdigheter, däribland tekniska färdigheter och yrkeskunnande, för sysselsättning, anständigt arbete och entreprenörskap.

description.narrative: The Sida support to the project, Career Guidance and Counselling in secondary schools in Cambodia, jointly organised and implemented by Arbetsförmedlingen (the Swedish National Employment Service) and the Finn Church Aid (Kirkon Ulkomaanapu - Kyrkans Utlandshjälp) started on January 1, 2019. This first and a half year has proved that these two organisations fully deliver on the planned goals. One of the outcomes is that the project has managed to raise to understanding of the importance of career guidance and counselling for students as a part of economic and social development of the country. One important issue is that the unique collaboration between two ministries in Cambodia, the Ministry of Education Youth and Sport (MoEYS) and the Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training (MoLVT), mainly though the National Employment Agency (NEA), has been strengthened based on the earlier programmes implemented by the two partners. During 2019 MoEYS increased work on policy development in the area, including career guidance and counselling in the teacher training curriculum of the Teacher Training Centres for lower secondary school teachers, and included the area in the Education Strategic Plan 2019-2023. The cooperation between the key implementers of the project, Arbetsförmedlingen, Finn Church Aid (FCA), Vocational Orientation Department (VOD) of MoeYS and National Employment Agency (NEA) have become stronger during the period. The project coordinating meetings have been held to ensure ownership, collaboration and trust. Career guidance and counselling has been introduced to local authorities including Provincial Office of Education (POE)s, District Office of Education (DOE)s, and school principals, who have expressed their support to the project. Twenty schools have been selected with the support from VOD, POEs and DOEs to be the project’s target schools. In the new school year 2019-2020, which just began in November, 9 of out 20 schools have already allocated classroom guidance to students even though the counsellors have not received a complete basic career guidance and counselling training yet. 60 new counsellors (50% female) started the basic career guidance and counselling training for five days. Training pre-tests and post-tests shows that the majority of career guidance and counsellors reported the changes in confidence with new skills in applying student-centred approach. Career guidance and counselling was included into the revised curriculum of Regional Teacher Training Centres. The revision of the curriculum was led by the Teacher Training Department with support from the project. A draft version of a Nationwide Career Guidance and Counselling Policy was elaborated. The preparations for the establishment of two new Mobile Job Offices started and a fund manager was procured. The Covid-19 pandemic has disrupted the planned work in the project during the first half of 2020. Some activities planned have not taken place, either postponed or cancelled. A substantial part of the budget has been reallocated to deal with the closure of schools and the instructions during March to July not to physically gather teachers or other MoEYS’ personal. Instead a number of activities have taken place through on-line media and the counsellors have been active in supporting students during home schooling.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Gaza Community Mental Health Program 2019-2021
COVID-19 Gaza Community Mental Health Program 2019-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Gaza Community Mental Health Program (GCMHP) är en långsiktig partner till Sverige och grundades 1990 som en allmänt erkänd icke-statlig organisation som tillhandahåller specialiserade psykiatriska tjänster i Gaza. GCMHP fokuserar på att erbjuda hälsovårdstjänster och är en resurs för andra civilsamhällesorganisationer (CBO) i Gaza, hälsoministeriet och UNRWA. GCMHP: s uppdrag är: "Styrd av principerna om rättvisa och mänskliga rättigheter ger GCMHP inkluderande, integrerad och specialiserad samhällshälsovård i Palestina."
Sverige har stött GCMHP:s tidigare strategiperiod 2014-2018 tillsammans med Norge och Schweiz. Fokus för strategiperioden 2014-2018 var att stärka GCMHP: s organisationsstruktur för att förbättra förutsättningama för måluppfyllelse och effektiviteten i genomförandet av de mentala tjänster som levereras.
Fokus för GCMHP under den kommande strategiperioden 2019-2021 är att bidra till att förbättra befolkningens mentala välbefinnande i Gazaremsan genom att ge tillgång till specialiserade psykiatriska tjänster; ha mekanismer på plats för att ge snabb psykologiska assistans, rådgivning och hänvisningar till de som påverkas av trauma; fortsätta att expandera poolen av psykiatriska experter i Gaza genom att bygga upp kapaciteten hos vårdpersonal; Stödja relevanta organisationers kapacitet att tillhandahålla grundläggande vård, icke-specialiserat stöd och ett effektivt hänvisningssystem och fokusera på praktisk forskning.
Åtgärden innebär att Sveriges bidrag till GCMHP: s kärnbudget ska verka för följande tre strategiska mål: 1. Bidra till att förbättra befolkningens psykiska hälsa i Gazaremsan. 2. Stödja personal och andra aktörer att tillhandahålla lämplig fokuserad vård. och 3. stärka GCMHP: s ledarroll genom att utarbeta procedurer för genomförande av dessa aktiviteter, protokoll och forskning.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Gaza Community Mental Health Programme (GCMHP) is a long-term partner to Sweden and was established in 1990 as a recognized non-governmental organization that provides specialized mental health services in Gaza. GCMHP focuses on offering community mental health services and is a resource for other community based organizations (CBOs) in Gaza, the Ministry of Health, and UNRWA. GCMHP's mission is: 'guided by the principles of justice and human rights, GCMHP provides inclusive, integrated, and specialized community mental health services in Palestine.'
Sweden has supported GCMHP's previous strategic period 2014-2018 along with the Norwegian Representative Office and the Swiss Development Cooperation. The focus of the 2014-2018 strategic period was on strengthening the organizational structure of GCMHP to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the mental health services delivered.
The focus for GCMHP in the upcoming strategic period 2019-2021 is to contribute to improve the mental wellbeing of the population in the Gaza Strip through providing access to specialized mental health services; having emergency response mechanisms in place to provide first aid psychological interventions, counselling, and referrals to those impacted by trauma; continuing to expand the pool of mental health professionals in Gaza through building the capacity of health care professionals; support the capacity of relevant organizations to provide basic care, non-specialized support, and an effective referral system; and focusing on action-oriented research.
The intervention entails Sweden's contribution to GCMHP's core budget to work towards the following three strategic goals: 1. contribute to improving the mental health situation of the population in the Gaza Strip; 2. support the capacity of professionals and other actors to provide appropriate focused care; and 3. strengthen GCMHP's leadership role through implementing model procedures, protocols, and research.

Sweden plans to provide core support to GCMHP to fund its Strategic Plan for 2019-2021 with the following mission: 'Guided by the principles of justice and human rights, GCMHP provides inclusive, integrated, and specialized community mental health services in Palestine.' GCMHP has set the following three strategic objectives to achieve its mission: (1) to contribute to improving the mental health situation of the population in the Gaza Strip and activating the rapid response mechanism in case of emergency; (2) to support the capacity of professionals and other actors to provide appropriate focused care through academic and professional programs; (3) to strengthen GCMHP's leadership role through implementing model procedures, protocols, and research. GCMHP throughout its various interventions and quality services aims at improving the psychological wellbeing and coping and resilience of its different target groups. Under the first strategic objective, the target groups are: indirect victims of human rights violations and traumatic events, children and youth under eighteen years old suffering from mental and psychological disorders, individuals suffering from chronic psychiatric and pervasive development disorders. Under the second strategic objective, the target groups are: CBOs, NGOs, and medical care facilities to strengthen their capacity to provide non-specialized mental health and psychosocial support services, to increase the coverage of available mental health services across Gaza. Building the capacity of organizations through focusing on the third level intervention pyramid for mental health and psychosocial support will allow trainees to be able to take care of basic mental care conditions, which would give GCMHP more room to focus on specialized mental health services.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Gaza Community Mental Health Program (GCMHP) är en långsiktig partner till Sverige och grundades 1990 som en allmänt erkänd icke-statlig organisation som tillhandahåller specialiserade psykiatriska tjänster i Gaza. GCMHP fokuserar på att erbjuda hälsovårdstjänster och är en resurs för andra civilsamhällesorganisationer (CBO) i Gaza, hälsoministeriet och UNRWA. GCMHP: s uppdrag är: "Styrd av principerna om rättvisa och mänskliga rättigheter ger GCMHP inkluderande, integrerad och specialiserad samhällshälsovård i Palestina."
Sverige har stött GCMHP:s tidigare strategiperiod 2014-2018 tillsammans med Norge och Schweiz. Fokus för strategiperioden 2014-2018 var att stärka GCMHP: s organisationsstruktur för att förbättra förutsättningama för måluppfyllelse och effektiviteten i genomförandet av de mentala tjänster som levereras.
Fokus för GCMHP under den kommande strategiperioden 2019-2021 är att bidra till att förbättra befolkningens mentala välbefinnande i Gazaremsan genom att ge tillgång till specialiserade psykiatriska tjänster; ha mekanismer på plats för att ge snabb psykologiska assistans, rådgivning och hänvisningar till de som påverkas av trauma; fortsätta att expandera poolen av psykiatriska experter i Gaza genom att bygga upp kapaciteten hos vårdpersonal; Stödja relevanta organisationers kapacitet att tillhandahålla grundläggande vård, icke-specialiserat stöd och ett effektivt hänvisningssystem och fokusera på praktisk forskning.
Åtgärden innebär att Sveriges bidrag till GCMHP: s kärnbudget ska verka för följande tre strategiska mål: 1. Bidra till att förbättra befolkningens psykiska hälsa i Gazaremsan. 2. Stödja personal och andra aktörer att tillhandahålla lämplig fokuserad vård. och 3. stärka GCMHP: s ledarroll genom att utarbeta procedurer för genomförande av dessa aktiviteter, protokoll och forskning.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Gaza Community Mental Health Programme (GCMHP) is a long-term partner to Sweden and was established in 1990 as a recognized non-governmental organization that provides specialized mental health services in Gaza. GCMHP focuses on offering community mental health services and is a resource for other community based organizations (CBOs) in Gaza, the Ministry of Health, and UNRWA. GCMHP's mission is: 'guided by the principles of justice and human rights, GCMHP provides inclusive, integrated, and specialized community mental health services in Palestine.'
Sweden has supported GCMHP's previous strategic period 2014-2018 along with the Norwegian Representative Office and the Swiss Development Cooperation. The focus of the 2014-2018 strategic period was on strengthening the organizational structure of GCMHP to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the mental health services delivered.
The focus for GCMHP in the upcoming strategic period 2019-2021 is to contribute to improve the mental wellbeing of the population in the Gaza Strip through providing access to specialized mental health services; having emergency response mechanisms in place to provide first aid psychological interventions, counselling, and referrals to those impacted by trauma; continuing to expand the pool of mental health professionals in Gaza through building the capacity of health care professionals; support the capacity of relevant organizations to provide basic care, non-specialized support, and an effective referral system; and focusing on action-oriented research.
The intervention entails Sweden's contribution to GCMHP's core budget to work towards the following three strategic goals: 1. contribute to improving the mental health situation of the population in the Gaza Strip; 2. support the capacity of professionals and other actors to provide appropriate focused care; and 3. strengthen GCMHP's leadership role through implementing model procedures, protocols, and research.

Sweden plans to provide core support to GCMHP to fund its Strategic Plan for 2019-2021 with the following mission: 'Guided by the principles of justice and human rights, GCMHP provides inclusive, integrated, and specialized community mental health services in Palestine.' GCMHP has set the following three strategic objectives to achieve its mission: (1) to contribute to improving the mental health situation of the population in the Gaza Strip and activating the rapid response mechanism in case of emergency; (2) to support the capacity of professionals and other actors to provide appropriate focused care through academic and professional programs; (3) to strengthen GCMHP's leadership role through implementing model procedures, protocols, and research. GCMHP throughout its various interventions and quality services aims at improving the psychological wellbeing and coping and resilience of its different target groups. Under the first strategic objective, the target groups are: indirect victims of human rights violations and traumatic events, children and youth under eighteen years old suffering from mental and psychological disorders, individuals suffering from chronic psychiatric and pervasive development disorders. Under the second strategic objective, the target groups are: CBOs, NGOs, and medical care facilities to strengthen their capacity to provide non-specialized mental health and psychosocial support services, to increase the coverage of available mental health services across Gaza. Building the capacity of organizations through focusing on the third level intervention pyramid for mental health and psychosocial support will allow trainees to be able to take care of basic mental care conditions, which would give GCMHP more room to focus on specialized mental health services.

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen syftar till att stärka lokala demokratiska strukturer och bidra till skapandet av ett mer inkluderande, sammanhängande och ansvarstagande samhälle som kommer att resultera i en förbättring av levnadsvillkoren för medborgare i Zimbabwe.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The intervention seeks to strengthen democratic culture and contribute to the creation of a more inclusive, cohesive and accountable society which will result in the improvement of living conditions for citizens in Zimbabwe.

The intervention is expected to acheive the following: 1.1 Development objectiveEnhanced democratic governance contributing to improved living conditions for citizens in Zimbabwe 1.2 Overall Programme Objective (Impact)Citizens are enjoying their rights to quality and gender responsive social services from transparent and accountable local authorities 1.3 Expected outcomesOutcome 1: Increased meaningful participation of citizens (women, men, young people and vulnerable people) in selected rural and urban areas in local governance Outcome 2: Enhanced transparency and accountability of local government systems and structures in selected rural and urban local authorities. Outcome 3: Strengthened capacity of selected civil society organisations to effectively support citizens (women, men, young people and vulnerable people) to meaningfully participate in local governance and influence policies and budgets.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: The report being assessed is a four months period report 1 September 2018 to 31 December 2018. During the four months under review the programme was able to achieve results that would normally take long to achieve within a short space of time because, the interventions built on the previous work by implementing partners in the same project area. The use of existing structures also contributed to the success of the programme during the reporting period. A more comprehensive assessment will be done at the end of 2020. The activities in the four months will be included in this 2020 reports. However, during the period under review, right holders assumed their critical oversight and monitoring roles on local authority performance and were able to bring duty bearers to account. This has in some areas contributed to increased uptake and responsiveness of duty bearers to rights holders' service delivery demands. The capacity building component of the programme saw an improved capacity of CSOs partners to form strategic alliances for synergies around common interest issues affecting holders well being. The young people through innovative youth friendly social accountability platforms were able to access strategic information on governance. The youth and women participation in governance issues was visible during the period under review, with women's voices advocating for improved service delivery. These results were achieved at the backdrop of CSOs shrinking space as the Government continues to institute restrictive measures which make work of civil society organisations difficult. Inconsistent economic policies, lack of fiscal discipline and corruption increased political tensions and on the part of government has contributed to the making the operating environment difficult. The Embassy is in constant dialogue with Diakonia on the effects of these factors on the programme.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Stödet till ”Access to Health Fund” syftar till att öka tillgången till grundläggande hälsotjänster för de mest sårbara människorna i konfliktdrabbade områden.
Två grundläggande prioriteringar för Access to Health Fund är 1) fokus på konfliktdrabbade områden, och 2) fokus på jämlikhet genom ett rättighetsbaserat tillvägagångssätt som främjar icke-diskriminering och uttryckligen riktar sig till de mest sårbara människorna i konfliktdrabbade och svårtillgängliga områden. Access to Health Fund är en givargemensam fond där Schweiz, Storbritannien, USA och Sverige ingår.
Tematiskt ligger fokus på mödra- och barnhälsovård, sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter, nutrition, malaria, tuberkulos, HIV, drogmissbruk, hälsovård i fängelser, infrastruktur samt stärkande av hälsosystemet. Alla insatser kommer att ligga i linje med Myanmars nationella hälsoplan (Myanmar National Health Plan 2017-2021). Den nationella hälsoplanen togs fram med deltagande från alla relevanta aktörer, inklusive etniska hälsoorganisationer.
Geografiskt kommer Access to Health Fund att prioritera insatser i staterna Rakhine, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah och Mon, samtliga drabbade av aktiva eller latenta konflikter och alla med mycket låga hälsoindikatorer. Genom att lägga fokus på dessa områden kommer fonden att nå de områden i Myanmar med sämst tillgång till hälsovård, inklusive områden där staten inte har kontroll, samt de mest sårbara grupperna.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The support to Access to Health Fund aims to increase access to quality essential health services for underserved and vulnerable people in conflict-affected areas, and to enable the health system to sustain these gains.
The Access to Health fund builds on two core priorities which are 1) focus on conflict-affected areas, and 2) focus on equity, adopting a human rights based approach to health promoting inclusiveness, and explicitly targeting underserved and vulnerable populations. The Fund is a multi-donor health fund, funded by Switzerland, United Kingdom, USA and Sweden.
The thematic focus areas of the Access to Health Fund will be Maternal, Newborn and Child Health, Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights, Nutrition, Tuberculosis, HIV prevention, Health Consequences of Drug Use, Health in Prisons, Malaria, Infrastructure as well as Health Systems strengthening - all aligned to Myanmar's National Health Plan 2017-2021. The National Health Plan was developed with participation from all key stakeholders, including the health organisations of various ethnic groups.
The Access to Health Fund will concentrate its interventions in Rakhine, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah and Mon, all states affected by latent or active conflict and all with very low health indicators. The reason behind the Access to Health Fund is prioritizing services in these areas is because access to health services are extremely low. By focusing on these areas, the Fund will be targeting some of Myanmar’s least equitable access-to-health situations and some of the country’s most vulnerable groups, in places that the government often is not able to reach and support.

The objective of Access to Health Fund is to increase access to quality essential health services for underserved and vulnerable people in conflict-affected areas, and to enable the health system to sustain these gains. The foundation of the Access to Health Fund is to focus on conflict-affected areas and to focus on equity. The Access to Health Fund is adopting a rights-based approach promoting inclusiveness, and explicitly targeting underserved and vulnerable populations. This focus on equity defines, to a large extent, the population the Fund will strive to serve. The desired impact of the Access to Health Fund is: - Better overall health status of populations in remote and conflict-affected areas - Reduced health inequalities This will be achieved through focusing activities on 1) increased population access to and use of services (within MNCH, SRHR, Nutrition, Malaria, Tuberculosis, HIV prevention, Health Consequences of Drug Use and Health in Prisons 2) increased collaboration of Government and Ethnic Health Organisations 3) Strengthened Health Systems. The Access to Health Fund will concentrate its interventions in Rakhine, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah and Mon, all states affected by latent or active conflict and all with very low health indicators. The reason behind the Access to Health fund is prioritizing services in these areas is because access to health services are extremely low. By focusing on these areas, the Fund will be targeting some of Myanmar’s least equitable access-to-health situations and some of the country’s most vulnerable groups, in places that the government often is not able to reach and support. Universal Health Coverage, the country's goal for 2030, requires access to health for populations throughout the country, and can only be achieved through closer cooperation and coordination with EHOs and their partners as well as ensuring referrals within the overall health system. The recent participation of EHOs in the definition of the National Health Plan, and their explicit responsibility in the delivery of the plan, are indications on the role that these organisations can play. The Fund will continue to promote and support such participation. In the design of the program of the Access to Health Fund, an analysis at the State level, combined with stakeholder consultations (with MoHS, implementing partners, EHOs) has been carried out and will continue. The analysis aims to gage the specific and diverse population needs in program geographies, and to identify appropriate and effective interventions to deliver the outcomes. The program indicators will be revised in line with forthcoming discussions. For the majority of indicators under MNCH, SRHR, and Nutrition, results are based on the national Health Management Information System data as the Fund will be supporting a Township-wide outreach, planning, and commodity supplies to health volunteers. At this stage of the Access to Health Fund, this description is by definition general, lacking the specific indicators and targets that will follow detailed calls for proposals, grant negotiations, and the establishment of defined programs. Examples of indicators for SRHR are Modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (MCPR) among married women; Number of young people (aged 10 to 24) reached by SRHR education via interpersonal communication approach; and number of post-abortion care services provided to women through public sector service providers. A result-oriented monitoring and evaluation framework will be finalized after grant negotiations with implementing partners. Considering that the focus on conflict areas have significantly increased as well as the proportion of funds invested in conflict affected townships, it is important to have realistic expectations on health results, and to have a long-term approach. It is not uncommon that when inaccessible areas open up a "backlog" of health needs, long left unattended, is released. Therefore one should expect indicators to get worse before improving.

participating-org.narrative: UNOPS/United Nations Office for Project Services
United Nations Office for Project Services

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

The Access to Health Fund will concentrate its interventions in Rakhine, Chin, Kachin, Shan, Kayin, Kayah and Mon, all states affected by latent or active conflict and all with very low health indicators. The reason behind the Access to Health fund is prioritizing services in these areas is because access to health services are extremely low. By focusing on these areas, the Fund will be targeting some of Myanmar’s least equitable access-to-health situations and some of the country’s most vulnerable groups, in places that the government often is not able to reach and support. Universal Health Coverage, the country's goal for 2030, requires access to health for populations throughout the country, and can only be achieved through closer cooperation and coordination with EHOs and their partners as well as ensuring referrals within the overall health system. The recent participation of EHOs in the definition of the National Health Plan, and their explicit responsibility in the delivery of the plan, are indications on the role that these organisations can play. The Fund will continue to promote and support such participation. In the design of the program of the Access to Health Fund, an analysis at the State level, combined with stakeholder consultations (with MoHS, implementing partners, EHOs) has been carried out and will continue. The analysis aims to gage the specific and diverse population needs in program geographies, and to identify appropriate and effective interventions to deliver the outcomes. The program indicators will be revised in line with forthcoming discussions. For the majority of indicators under MNCH, SRHR, and Nutrition, results are based on the national Health Management Information System data as the Fund will be supporting a Township-wide outreach, planning, and commodity supplies to health volunteers. At this stage of the Access to Health Fund, this description is by definition general, lacking the specific indicators and targets that will follow detailed calls for proposals, grant negotiations, and the establishment of defined programs. Examples of indicators for SRHR are Modern Contraceptive Prevalence Rate (MCPR) among married women; Number of young people (aged 10 to 24) reached by SRHR education via interpersonal communication approach; and number of post-abortion care services provided to women through public sector service providers. A result-oriented monitoring and evaluation framework will be finalized after grant negotiations with implementing partners. Considering that the focus on conflict areas have significantly increased as well as the proportion of funds invested in conflict affected townships, it is important to have realistic expectations on health results, and to have a long-term approach. It is not uncommon that when inaccessible areas open up a "backlog" of health needs, long left unattended, is released. Therefore one should expect indicators to get worse before improving.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

title.narrative: COVID-19 NPA 2018: basic services, civil society in Syria
COVID-19 NPA 2018: grundläggande samhällstjänster, civilsamhälle i Syrien

description.narrative: Det långsiktiga målet för insatsen är en ökad möjlighet för människor att påverka beslutsprocesser i sina lokalsamhällen. Att stödja syriska civilsamhällsorganisationer samt öka deras förmåga att organisera och mobilisera människor å ena sidan, och å andra sidan påverka lokala samhällsstyrningsstrukturer och makthavare är avgörande för att öka människors deltagande i sina lokalsamhällen. NPA identifierar följande tre förändringar som nödvändiga för att stärka människors inflytande över lokalt beslutsfattande, vilka därför utgör programmets tre huvudsakliga resultatområden: (1) syriska civila samhällsorganisationer påverkar lokala beslutsprocesser (2) Människor har större tillgång till lokala maktinnehavare och styrningsstrukturer, och (3) Lokala maktinnehavare och styrelseformer svarar bättre på medborgarnas behov NPA identifierar fyra huvudsakliga lokala samhällsstyrningsstrukturer: kommunal lokal förvaltning i regimkontrollerade områden; kommuner i oppositionskontrollerade områden; försoningskommittéer eller andra liknande samhällsstyrningsstrukturer i områden under försonings- eller vapenviloavtal; samt självstyre- och lokal förvaltning i områden kontrollerade av PYD. Dessa överlappar dessutom med andra makthavare, såsom beväpnade grupper, stammar, familjer och inflytelserika affärsmän och näringsidkare. Inom alla de styrande strukturer som beskrivs bedömmer NPA människors förmåga att påverka beslutsfattandet som svagt. Det är avgörande för att stärka lokala samhällsstyrningsstrukturers interaktion med människor, stärka människors tillgång till dessa strukturer och att möjliggöra syrianiska CSOs som representerar människors intressen, att rikta sig till lokala maktinnehavare. För att de syriska CSO:erna bättre ska kunna påverka lokala beslutsfattande anser NPA att partners måste bygga sina organisationer med inriktning på både demokratisk intern praxis, förmåga att mobilisera i samhället och bygga allianser. Om syriska partners utvecklas som mer demokratiska och starkare organisationer, kommer de bättre att kunna organisera och representera människor på lokal nivå, eftersom detta ökar deras trovärdighet och representativitet. Detta inkluderar bättre representationer av kvinnor, minoriteter och ungdomar. NPA anser vidare att sådana organisationer som kan identifiera gemensamma intressen och agendor baserade på demokratiska fundament och respekt för mänskliga rättigheter har en bättre grund för alliansbyggande. Sådana allianser skulle i sin tur göra organisationerna till starkare förespråkare för människors intressen gentemot de lokala maktinnehavarna, och ibland även på regional, nationell eller internationell nivå när detta skulle vara relevant för deras orsak.På grund av historiskt ansträngda förhållandet mellan människor och samhällsstyrningsstruktur i Syrien bedömmer också NPA att folk är ovilliga att involvera sig i beslutsprocesser. Det är möjligt att CSOs i detta program strävar efter att samla beslutsfattare och andra intressenter för att förbättra responsen och ansvaret i sina lokalsamhällen. CSO kan spela en viktig roll för att främja och underlätta kommunikationen mellan makthavare och lokalbefolkningen i de olika områdena. CSO:er kommer att spela en viktig roll för att kartlägga behov och möjligheter i lokalsamhällen i syfte att informera beslutsfattare och lokala styrningsstrukturer. Denna process kommer att åtföljas av initiativ från CSOs för att öka medvetenheten om människor i lokalbefolkningen, om politisk kultur och samhällsengagemang. Detta kommer även att främja vikten av samexistens, acceptans för andras åsikter och kvinnors, ungdomars och minoritets roll i beslutsprocesserna.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Norsk Folkehjelp (NPA) har ansökt om medel för genomförande av programmet "Civil Society and People’s Participation in Syria 2018-2020". Det övergripande målet är att stärka det civila samhället och stödja upprättandet av processer och metoder för att förbättra kvaliteten och omfattningen av människors inflytande på beslutsfattande på lokal nivå. Ett tydligt fokus kommer ligga på att stärka syriska partners kapacitet och förmåga att påverka lokalsamfund. Förändringsteorin fokuserar på kapacitet, attityder, beteenden och att relationer mellan relevanta aktörer förändras: människor, syriska civilsamhällspartners, lokala styrningsstrukturer och andra ansvariga makthavare i samhällena. Programmet genomförs av Norsk folkhjälp (Norwegian People's Aid, NPA) under perioden 2018-2020. Sida stödjer programmet med 54.700.000 SEK.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Norwegian People's Aid (NPA) has applied for a grant for the implementation of the Civil Society and People's Participation in Syria 2018-2020 program. The overall objective is to strengthen civil society and support the establishment of processes and methods to improve the quality and extent of people's influence on decision-making in local government. The approach is based on a grassrot perspective. A clear focus will be on strengthening Syrian partners' capacities and capacity to influence communities. Change theory focuses on capacity, attitudes, behavior and relationships between relevant actors: people, Syrian civil society partners, local governance structures and other powerholders in society. The program is conducted by Norwegian People's Aid (NPA) during the period 2018-2020. Sida supports the program by 54,700,000 SEK.

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

description.narrative: The project “Civil Society and People’s Participation in Syria” (from now CSPPS) is implemented by NPA between June 2018 – December 2021. This Conclusion on performance covers the period June 2019 - July 2020. The project is implemented in North-East, North-West, and Central Areas of Syria through eight local partners. The Embassy of Sweden in Beirut (EoS) considers that the partners activities are appropriate to reach the planned project outcomes that are outlined as follow: 1: Syrian Civil Society Organizations influence local decision-making processes, 2: People have greater access to local power holders and local governance structures and 3: Community leaders and local governance structures respond better to citizens’ local needs. Capacity building is also a project objective and large part of the activities and of the funding is used for that purpose. NPA started the intervention using a base line research carried out during 2018 which has proven to be an effective method to identify areas of intervention, possible partners, capacities and needs, as well as funding possibilities. It is possible to state that the first achieved result was the obtained capacity to settle partnership with local civil society organization in a complex conflict environment. NPA has reported several results during the period that can be summarized as follow:-Regarding the capacity of partners and the Syrian civil society organizations possibility to influence local decision-making processes: NPA assesses that conducted trainings have helped partners to better coordinate their efforts and promote joint advocacy activities. The creation of an online Northeast NGOs Platform and the coordinated response of the civil society in response to the Turkish military operation in North East Syria in October 2019 are examples of the improved coordination capacity. Partners succeeded in forming alliances and coordinated with other civil society organizations. It is specially highlighted the work of the partner organization ERIDU that managed to include minorities in the coordination efforts.-Regarding greater access to local power holders and local governance structures by the civil society it is highlighted that the partners organizations have managed to bring local community leaders and governance bodies together, opening spaces for dialogue and building trust to improve engagement with the population. NPA has witnessed a change in attitudes, behavior, and relations between civil society organization partners on one hand, and between partners and other local actors on the other hand. Furthermore, NPA inform that more than 20 local development committees and youth networks have been formed with partners support during 2019 in North-West Syria. The committees are working to increase the level of conflict awareness and are supporting local level peace dialogue.-Regarding needs response by Community leaders and local governance structures it is reported that partners are advancing in advocacy and dialogue. It is quoted as example the work of the local partner ASO that supported actors in North-East Syria to participate in the Syria Constitutional Committee process through advocacy towards self-administration and a Kurdish National Council (KNC). -In terms of Capacity development outcomes, NPA has provided the partner organizations swith regular training and mentorship on financial, procurement, human resources and project management, as well as on monitoring and evaluation methods. The result of this process will be externally evaluated in July 2020. NPA has also organised coordination activities to provide local partners with a common arena for dialogue. Those meeting resulted in an improved communication among partners, joint context analyses and coordination to provide inputs for the Geneva process. Until July 2020 an approximately amount of SEK 25 000 000 has been implemented. Furthermore, during the reported period there were two major crises; the Turkish military operation in October 2019 in some areas of implementation and the Covid-19 pandemic. It is assessed by EoS that NPA did a swift adaptation of the implementation capacity during these crises and managed to continue implementing the project. There were a good level of communication and dialogue with and NPA during these both crises. The EoS has visited NPA offices in Beirut twice during the year and one biannual meeting with the organization was held in January 2020. Due to the Turkish military operation in October the planned participation in the partner organization in Erbil in North-East Syria annual meeting was cancelled. Another visit was planned for May 2020, but again cancelled and this time due to Covid-19. The EoS has done followed up on project developments through online meetings and dialogue with the organization as no physical visits have been possible.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Community Security and Stabilization Programme Sudan 2018-2020
COVID-19 Community Security and Stabilization Programme Sudan 2018-2020

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 UNDPs landkontor i Sudan har ansökt hos Sida om finansiering för sitt program "Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) in Sudan, 2015-2020". Överipande målsättning med programmet är att bidra till stabilitet och ökad motståndskraft i 93 byar i fem stater i södra Sudan; South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile and North Kordofan. Byarna har valts ut på basis av multidimensionell fattigdom, utsatthet och risk för konflikt, hög arbetslöshet (särskilt bland ungdomar och kvinnor), och för att dessa lokalsamhällen tar emot stora grupper av internflyktingar, flyktingar och migranter. Små ekonomiska möjligheter och resursbrist har lämnat dessa byar särskilt utsatta vilket ökar risken för konflikter av olika slag. Programmet avser bidra till ökade försörjningsmöjligheter och stärkt socio-ekonomisk motståndskraft genom att nå bl.a. arbetslösa ungdomar, flyktingar/migranter och utsatta kvinnor med insatser i de utvalda byarna.
Programmets budget är 17 MUSD. Givare inkluderar Japan, Italien, UK och Spainen. Programmet har nyligen påbörjat en andra fas 2018-2020 under vilken 9,300 personer förväntas nås direkt och 279,000 personer indirekt av insatserna i valda byar och lokalsamhällen. Sida planerar ett stöd till programmet på 45 MSEK 2018-2020.
Programmets målsättningar är:
1) Stärka motståndskraften hos arbetslösa ungdomar som annars löper risken att radikaliseras och mobiliseras i Sudans konflikter, bl.a. genom stöd till ökade försörjningsmöjligheter.
2) Stödja stabilitet och fredsbyggande genom ökad motståndskraft i de lokalsamhällen som tar emot flyktingar och migranter från Sydsudan och internflyktingar pga konflikt, bl.a. genom uppbyggnad av socio-ekonomisk infrastruktur.
3) Stärka lokalsamhällen, staters men även den nationella nivåns kapacitet och förmåga till fredsbyggande och forsatt engagemang i fredsinitiativ, positiv transformering av ungas engagemang, nätverkande, dilaog och lärande.
Programaktiviteter fokuseras till 1) alternativa försörjningsmöjligheter för arbetslösa ungdomar inom tex jordbruk, yrkesutbildningar m.m. 2) ersättningsinvesteringar av basal infrastruktur som t.ex. vattenpumpar i samhällen drabbade av konflikt, 3) stärkt motståndskraft och socialt kapital 4) kapacitetsuppbyggnad av s.k. Community Management Committees (CMCs) och lokal offentlig verksamhet, startbidrag för lokal företagsverksamhet, samarbete med den privata sektorn och finansiella institutioner, korttidsarbeten m.m.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 UNDP country office in Sudan has approached Sida for funding of its Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) in Sudan which runs between 2015-2020. The overall objective of the programme is to contribute to the stability and resilience of 93 communities in the five states South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile and North Kordofan. The targeted communities were selected on the basis of a multidimensional poverty and conflict exposure analysis conducted by UNDP and are characterized by being on the verge of conflict, suffering from high unemployment rates (particularly among women and youths) and/or hosting large groups of IDPs/refugees/migrants. Limited economic opportunities and resource scarcity has further exacerbated development challenges in many of these communities and are likely to contribute to distress and conflicts in the near future if left unaddressed. The programme aims at building inclusive livelihoods and strengthen socio-economic resilience of the targeted communities by addressing the specific needs of e.g. unemployed youth, displaced population and women at risk.
The programme budget is US$ 17,066,000. Other donors include Japan, Italy, UK and Spain. The programme has recently (January 2018) entered into its second phase during which it is planning to reach a minimum of 9,300 direct and 279,000 indirect beneficiaries in the prioritized communities. Sida is considering a support of approx. 45 000 000 SEK during 2018-2020.
The specific objectives of the programme are:
1) To strengthen the resilience of unemployed youth who have the potential to be radicalized and mobilized to join conflicts by the provision of livelihood support and generation of the rural economy in the southern States bordering South Sudan
2) To promote stability and peace-building by strengthening the resilience of communities hosting refugees and migrants from South Sudan and IDPs resulting from internal conflict by providing socio-economic infrastructure and assets to benefit all.
3) To enhance the capacity of peacebuilding structures at the community, state, and national levels to continue promoting and engaging in peace initiatives, positive transformation of youth, networking and provide space for dialogue and learning.
Programme activities focus on 1) providing alternative livelihoods for unemployed youth through, e.g., farming activities, vocational skills training, workshops and awareness raising; 2) replacement of basic infrastructure (e.g. water pumps) in conflict-ridden communities; 3) strengthening of community resilience and social cohesion; 4) capacity development of Community Management Committees (CMCs) and local government entities. Start-up support for local businesses, facilitation of linkages with the private sector and financial institutions, creation of short-term jobs and support to community-based initiatives will also form part of the comprehensive programme.

The UNDP Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) intends to contribute to the stability and resilience of the selected vulnerable communities, which are at the risk of being drawn into conflicts in six states of Sudan; South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile, Sennar and North Kordofan. It aims to achieve this by: (i) Strengthening resilience of target communities through provision of diversified alternative livelihoods for at-risk groups primarily focussing on unemployed youth who are at risk of being drawn into conflicts, refugees, IDPs, returnees and at-risk women, (ii) Creating a conducive environment for graduated small arms control at the sub regional, national and community level to reduce the occurrence of armed conflicts and loss of life, (iii) Provision of socio-economic infrastructure in targeted communities having direct relevance to the conflicts, (iv) Strengthening the communities to manage the community infrastructure and NGO/CBO service providers for improved service delivery to target beneficiaries and communities for long term peace and stability, (v) Promoting cross-border cooperation among the communities and authorities for enhancing stability at the bordering communities.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.
16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

16.a - Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.

16.a - Stärka berörda nationella institutioner, bland annat genom internationellt samarbete, i syfte att bygga upp kapacitet på alla nivåer, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, för att förebygga våld och bekämpa terrorism och brottslighet.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Between January 2019 and December 2019, C2SP supported 13 communities across states (White Nile, Blue Nile, North Kordofan, West Kordofan and South Kordofan), assisting a total of 29.250 beneficiaries (50% women) with the additional Sida funding. In total, the C2SP has reached 41 communities since its inception in 2015 (including the 13 Sida funded communities). Under Output 1, providing alternative livelihood support to at-risk/unemployed youth, a total 1600 households were assisted during the reporting period. Activities included training on soap making, provision of festival equipment for women, and the establishment of show clubs for youth, grinding mills. Under Output 2, relating to the provision of socio-economic infrastructure, assets or basic facilities in support of economic recovery and conflict mitigation established, C2SP assisted all 13 targeted communities with infrastructure and/or assets such as tractors, harvesters, trailers and wide level discs with a total of 23 assets. The equipment is owned by the community and is managed by a Community Management Committee (CMC), which arealso established by the C2SP (a total of 13 were established with Sida funding in 2019). Under Output 3, dealing with peacebuilding and reconciliation, 12 peacebuilding sub-committees (to the CMCs) were established with Sida funding. The committees are trained in reconciliation and conflict management, and succeeded in resolving a total of 21 different disputes in 2019. Under Output 4, strengthening the capacity of government and local service providers, a total of 3 government institutions, 13 NGOs have been provided technical assistance and trainings. During the 2019 implementation period, C2SP faced a number of significant challenges. The biggest challenge was the civil unrest/revolution, which both affected the movement of staff and caused major disruptions in the government's operations. The cash and fuel shortages also proved difficult and caused delays in the operations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 UNDP country office in Sudan has approached Sida for funding of its Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) in Sudan which runs between 2015-2020. The overall objective of the programme is to contribute to the stability and resilience of 93 communities in the five states South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile and North Kordofan. The targeted communities were selected on the basis of a multidimensional poverty and conflict exposure analysis conducted by UNDP and are characterized by being on the verge of conflict, suffering from high unemployment rates (particularly among women and youths) and/or hosting large groups of IDPs/refugees/migrants. Limited economic opportunities and resource scarcity has further exacerbated development challenges in many of these communities and are likely to contribute to distress and conflicts in the near future if left unaddressed. The programme aims at building inclusive livelihoods and strengthen socio-economic resilience of the targeted communities by addressing the specific needs of e.g. unemployed youth, displaced population and women at risk.
The programme budget is US$ 17,066,000. Other donors include Japan, Italy, UK and Spain. The programme has recently (January 2018) entered into its second phase during which it is planning to reach a minimum of 9,300 direct and 279,000 indirect beneficiaries in the prioritized communities. Sida is considering a support of approx. 45 000 000 SEK during 2018-2020.
The specific objectives of the programme are:
1) To strengthen the resilience of unemployed youth who have the potential to be radicalized and mobilized to join conflicts by the provision of livelihood support and generation of the rural economy in the southern States bordering South Sudan
2) To promote stability and peace-building by strengthening the resilience of communities hosting refugees and migrants from South Sudan and IDPs resulting from internal conflict by providing socio-economic infrastructure and assets to benefit all.
3) To enhance the capacity of peacebuilding structures at the community, state, and national levels to continue promoting and engaging in peace initiatives, positive transformation of youth, networking and provide space for dialogue and learning.
Programme activities focus on 1) providing alternative livelihoods for unemployed youth through, e.g., farming activities, vocational skills training, workshops and awareness raising; 2) replacement of basic infrastructure (e.g. water pumps) in conflict-ridden communities; 3) strengthening of community resilience and social cohesion; 4) capacity development of Community Management Committees (CMCs) and local government entities. Start-up support for local businesses, facilitation of linkages with the private sector and financial institutions, creation of short-term jobs and support to community-based initiatives will also form part of the comprehensive programme.

The UNDP Community Security and Stabilization Programme (C2SP) intends to contribute to the stability and resilience of the selected vulnerable communities, which are at the risk of being drawn into conflicts in six states of Sudan; South Kordofan, Blue Nile, West Kordofan, White Nile, Sennar and North Kordofan. It aims to achieve this by: (i) Strengthening resilience of target communities through provision of diversified alternative livelihoods for at-risk groups primarily focussing on unemployed youth who are at risk of being drawn into conflicts, refugees, IDPs, returnees and at-risk women, (ii) Creating a conducive environment for graduated small arms control at the sub regional, national and community level to reduce the occurrence of armed conflicts and loss of life, (iii) Provision of socio-economic infrastructure in targeted communities having direct relevance to the conflicts, (iv) Strengthening the communities to manage the community infrastructure and NGO/CBO service providers for improved service delivery to target beneficiaries and communities for long term peace and stability, (v) Promoting cross-border cooperation among the communities and authorities for enhancing stability at the bordering communities.

16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.

5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt

5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.

description.narrative: Between January 2019 and December 2019, C2SP supported 13 communities across states (White Nile, Blue Nile, North Kordofan, West Kordofan and South Kordofan), assisting a total of 29.250 beneficiaries (50% women) with the additional Sida funding. In total, the C2SP has reached 41 communities since its inception in 2015 (including the 13 Sida funded communities). Under Output 1, providing alternative livelihood support to at-risk/unemployed youth, a total 1600 households were assisted during the reporting period. Activities included training on soap making, provision of festival equipment for women, and the establishment of show clubs for youth, grinding mills. Under Output 2, relating to the provision of socio-economic infrastructure, assets or basic facilities in support of economic recovery and conflict mitigation established, C2SP assisted all 13 targeted communities with infrastructure and/or assets such as tractors, harvesters, trailers and wide level discs with a total of 23 assets. The equipment is owned by the community and is managed by a Community Management Committee (CMC), which arealso established by the C2SP (a total of 13 were established with Sida funding in 2019). Under Output 3, dealing with peacebuilding and reconciliation, 12 peacebuilding sub-committees (to the CMCs) were established with Sida funding. The committees are trained in reconciliation and conflict management, and succeeded in resolving a total of 21 different disputes in 2019. Under Output 4, strengthening the capacity of government and local service providers, a total of 3 government institutions, 13 NGOs have been provided technical assistance and trainings. During the 2019 implementation period, C2SP faced a number of significant challenges. The biggest challenge was the civil unrest/revolution, which both affected the movement of staff and caused major disruptions in the government's operations. The cash and fuel shortages also proved difficult and caused delays in the operations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
